prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Specific powers of transferee court—Transferee court “jurisdiction”

para.paratext: The fact that the Panel has exercised jurisdiction over the case by ordering transfer does not have any impact on the power of the transferee court, other to vest it with jurisdiction over transferred actions. The transferee court's jurisdiction is no vaster than the transferor's jurisdiction over the transferred actions.

An important power of the courts that is particularly important to an MDL transferee judge is the power to enjoin litigants and their attorneys from commencing or prosecuting litigation in other forums. This power flows from the intersection of the Anti–Injunction Act, 28 U.S.C. § 2283, and the All Writs Act, 28 U.S.C. § 1651(a). A power to enjoin attempts by litigants in MDL litigation to have other courts take jurisdiction over the dispute is recognized in a number of cases.[1]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., Tires Products Liability Litigation, 333 F.3d 763, 765 (7th Cir. 2003) (injunction against have state court consider certifying overlapping class). For a thorough analysis of these issues, see Lonny Sheinkopf Hoffman, Syngenta, Stephenson and the Federal Injunctive Power, 37 Akron L. Rev. (2004). See also In re Checking Account Overdraft Litigation, 859 F. Supp. 2d 1313 (S.D. Fla. 2012) (denying stay, but enjoining party from effecting settlement in another federal court, relying on “first to file” rule).
